T = 490 °C. Conditions: FHCl = 16 mL/min, HCl/O2 = 0.25, FT = 160 mL/min, P = 1 bar. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Long-term stability test of CeO(12)-MnO x (13)/AlO3 catalyst at different reaction temperatures. Conditions: Wcat = 0.1 g, FHCl = 16 mL/min, HCl/O2 = 0.25, FT = 160 mL/min, P = 1 bar. (a) HCl/O2 = 2, (b) HCl/O2 = 2.5, (c) HCl/O2 = 3, (d) HCl/O2 = 4. Conditions: Wcat = 0.1 g, FHCl = 16 mL/min, FT = 160 mL/min, P = 1 bar. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Raman spectra of the fresh CeO2(12)-MnOx(13)/Al2O3 catalyst and those used at 430 °C and 450 °C and HCl/O2 = 4 for 30 h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRD patterns of used CeO2(12)-MnOx(13)/Al2O3 catalysts after 30 h run under different reaction condition (a) HCl/O2 = 2, (b) HCl/O2 = 2.5, (c) HCl/O2 = 3, (d) HCl/O2 = 4. Fig. 7 Improved Cl2 yield and stability of CeO2-MnOx/Al2O3 catalyst for HCl oxidation to Cl2 at higher reaction temperature Xin Tian Yaping Li Baining Lin Shuai Wang Yonghua Zhou * Hong Zhong * Hunan Provincial Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Utilization of Manganese Resources, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China Hunan Provincial Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Utilization of Manganese Resources College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Central South University Changsha 410083 China Hunan Provincial Key Laboratory of Efficient and Clean Utilization of Manganese Resources, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Central South University, Changsha 410083, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The effect of high reaction temperature on the activity and stability of CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst was investigated. The space time yield (STY) of Cl2 was significantly increased from 3.0 to 9.5 gCl2 gcat −1 h−1 at the same X HCl of 65 % by increasing reaction temperature from 430 to 490 °C and the catalyst could keep stable for at least 30 h under the harsh condition with HCl/O2 of 4. The pulse intake experiments results of HCl and O2 showed that increasing the reaction temperature from 430 °C to 490 °C was conducive to keep the adsorption balance of Cl* and O* on the catalyst surface, which was the key reason for the increase of STY and stability. The XRD characterization results verified the crystalline stability of CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst at 450 °C with HCl/O2 of 4. In this paper, CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 was proved to be a high active and excellent anti-chlorination catalyst at high reaction temperature, which supplied a novel alternative for the industrial application. Keywords High temperature HCl oxidation CeO2-MnOx/Al2O3 catalyst STY 1 Introduction Deacon process is a well-known technology to convert HCl to Cl2 by one step oxidation since 1870. And the higher Cl2 space time yield (STY) at moderate high HCl conversion (>65 %) and higher stability are the long-standing goals for the Deacon catalysts. Except the traditional CuO and Cr2O3 catalysts, CeO2 emerged as a new type of Deacon catalyst in view of its relatively high intrinsic stability than pure CuO and Cr2O3 [1,2]. Even though, the activity and stability of pure CeO2 still cannot satisfy the requirement of industry [1]. To improve the performance of CeO2 based catalyst, ZrO2 has been proved to be an efficient promoter as dopant or carrier [3–7]. In one aspect, the Cl2 yield could be improved because the dispersity of CeO2 was improved by ZrO2. In other aspect, the stability could also be improved via forming CexZryOz solid solution or core-shell composite with different morphology, including Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 nanofibers [8–10], Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 nanorods [11], CeO2 nano-cubes [12] and CeO2@ZrO2 [7,13]. In these cases, the bulk chlorination was efficiently inhibited and the obvious Ce loss in form of CeCl36 H2O was avoided under the harsh condition (HCl/O2 = 1–3). In our previous work, we found that MnO x was another excellent promoter for CeO2-based catalyst except ZrO2, considering the improved activity with x HCl of 72 % and a satisfactory stability at 430 °C under the mild reaction condition (HCl/O2 = 0.25) for at least 200 h [14]. As we know, to diminish the recycling amount of oxygen, the higher ratio of HCl/O2 is preferred in industry. How about the performance of CeO2-MnO x /Al2O3 catalyst under the higher ratio of HCl/O2? How to maintain its activity and stability under the harsh condition? These questions deserve to be further investigated. In addition, it is well known that the catalytic oxidation of HCl to Cl2 is exothermic and performed in the fixed-bed reactor. Due to the thermal-conduction limitation, the rising of the bed temperature is inevitable. How about the effect of high temperature on the performance of CeO2-MnO x /Al2O3 catalyst? It was only reported in a literature that as for CeO2 nanorods, the bulk chlorination could be weakened by rising temperature from 430 °C to 500 °C, while the reason was not given [11,15]. As for CeO2-MnO x /Al2O3 catalyst, how will it behave at the condition with both higher reaction temperature and higher ratio of HCl/O2? To answer the above questions, the effects of higher temperature (450−490 °C) than the normal operation temperature 430 °C on the activity (mainly Cl2 STY) and stability of CeO2-MnO x /Al2O3 catalyst were investigated in this paper. Except XRD characterizations of fresh and used catalysts, the pulse intake experiments of HCl and O2 at different temperatures were also carried out to detect the adsorption behavior of Cl* on the catalyst surface. 2 Experimental The CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method, the same as our previous work [12]. XRD patterns of samples were collected using a Rigaku D/max 2550 VB diffractometer with filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) from a generator operating at 40 kV and 450 mA. Raman spectra were achieved at room temperature on a LabRam HR Raman spectrometer (Horiba-Jobin Yvon) using a 532 nm laser with a 50 % neutral-density filter. The BET specific surface area of catalyst was measured by nitrogen physical adsorption-desorption isotherms at liquid-nitrogen temperature (77 K) by means of an automatic adsorption instrument (Quanta chromium Quadrawin gas sorption analyzer). The surface composition of the catalysts was quantified by X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) experiments (ESCALAB250Xi). The quantitative analysis of the XPS spectra was carried out by using the Avantage program. Catalytic performance tests for HCl oxidation were carried out in a self-assembly quartz fixed-bed tube reactor at a total pressure of 1 bar. The reactor was heated from room temperature to the reaction temperature at the rate of 4 °C/ min under N2 atmosphere before admitting a mixture with a total flow rate (FT) 160 mL/min. The flow rate of HCl gas stayed at 16 mL/min, and the HCl/O2 ratio ranged with N2 for balance. After 1−2 h reaction, the outcomes were absorbed by excessive potassium iodide solution, and the amount of chlorine was determined by iodometric titration [16]. The X HCl and STY were defined according to our previous work [14,17–19]. The pulse intake experiments of HCl and O2 on CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst at different temperatures were carried out and the experimental process was the same as the previous literature [20]. Typically, the catalyst was exposed in the stream of HCl and O2 with specific ratio at the reaction temperature for 4−5 h, and subsequently O2 was switched off for a period of time, and then O2 was restored. In all the time, the change trend of the activity was monitored. And the pulse measurement of HCl was performed similarly. 3 Results and discussion In our previous paper, the X HCl of CeO2(12)-MnOx(13)/Al2O3 catalyst reached 72 % at 430 °C, while the corresponding STY was only 1.96 gCl2 gcat −1 h−1, which had no significant advantage over other CeO2-based catalysts [4,21]. It is known that the X HCl is dependent of the dosage of catalyst and varies inversely with STY [22,23]. Therefore, the effects of catalyst dosage on the X HCl and the STY were investigated at reaction temperature of 430−490 °C as shown in Fig. 1 . It is observed that at the same X HCl of 65 %, the STY at 430 °C is about 3.0 gCl2 gcat −1 h−1 and it reaches about 6.5 gCl2 gcat −1 h−1 at 450 °C. In addition, the STY at 470 °C and 490 °C rise up to 9.5 gCl2 gcat −1 h-1. Therefore, it is obvious that the reaction temperature has a significant effect on the STY of catalyst, especially when the reaction temperature rises from 430 °C to 470 °C. Normally, it is recognized that STY is closely related to the dispersion of the active sites. In this paper, as for the specific CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst, the dispersion of the active sites is certain. So the effect of reaction temperature on STY can only be ascribed to the kinetic aspects, including the adsorption and desorption of reactants, which will be discussed in the following pulse intake experiments. In our previous work, the stability of CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst at 430 °C has been tested [14]. So the stability of CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst at higher reaction temperatures (450−490 °C) was tested here as shown in Fig. 2. It is obvious that CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst can still keep excellent stability with X HCl of 62–68 % and STY of 5.8–9.2 gCl2 gcat −1 h-1 in the 100 h test even at 450−490 °C with HCl/O2 of 0.25. The pulse intake experiments of HCl and O2 on CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst at different temperatures were determined as shown in Fig. 3 . It is observed that when O2 or HCl is switched off, the X HCl drops rapidly to zero, which indicates that the HCl oxidation to Cl2 over CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst follows the l-H mechanism, that is, the surface reaction mechanism [16]. At 430 °C, when O2 is restored, the X HCl becomes higher than the normal level and then gradually resumes it. This indicates that a large amount of Cl* is stored on the catalyst surface during the time of O2-off [20]. When O2 is turned on, the high coverage ratio of Cl* leads to a temporary high X HCl at the beginning time. In other words, the vacancies on the catalyst surface are much readily occupied by Cl* at 430 °C. In addition, it is noted that at 430 °C, it takes 11 h to resume the normal X HCl, and during this time, the normal coverage ratios of Cl* and O* are recovered gradually. At 450 °C, the gap between the normal X HCl and that at the beginning time of O2-on is decreased compared with 430 °C, and the time is shortened from 11 h to almost 5 h. When the reaction temperature rises to 470 °C and 490 °C, respectively, the gap becomes quite small and the X HCl is resumed quickly. These results show that high reaction temperature is helpful to decline the coverage of Cl* on the catalyst surface. As we know, the overwhelming adsorption of Cl* than O*, leads to desorption difficulty of Cl2, which is the main reason of the low activity and stability of the catalyst. In this paper, this problem is well solved by increasing reaction temperature. This means that high reaction temperature can quickly balance the competition adsorption of Cl* and O* on the surface of catalyst to improve the reaction activity and stability [3]. To characterize the coverage of Cl* and O* on the catalyst, the XPS experiments were carried out for the samples which was marked with star symbol in Fig. 3 (a, b). The XPS survey spectra, Ce 3d5/2 and Mn 2p3/2 spectra are shown in Fig. 4 . It is observed that the Ce 3d5/2 spectra in Fig. 4 (c, e) can be deconvoluted into three peaks, Ce4+(CeO2), Ce3+(CeCl3) and Ce3+(Ce2O3). When O2-on lasted for 1 h and 6 h at 430 ℃, respectively, the percentage of CeCl3/CeO2 is 0.483 and 0.330 correspondingly, indicating the gradual substitution of Cl* by O*. As for 450 ℃, the percentage of CeCl3/CeO2 is 0.405 and 0.360, respectively, which also indicates the substitution of Cl* by O*. As for Mn 2p3/2 spectra in Fig. 4 (d, f), no obvious change of MnCl2/(MnCl2+MnO2) is observed at both 430 ℃ and 450 ℃. This indicates that the coverage of Cl*and O* on Ce atoms is the main factor for catalysts activity. The stoichiometry of HCl/O2 for HCl oxidation reaction is 4, but in general, excessive oxygen (with HCl/O2 = 0.5–1) has to been co-fed to delay the deactivation of catalyst. The reaction condition with HCl/O2 >1 was commonly regarded as the harsh reaction condition [11]. The effect of reaction temperature on the stability of the catalyst under the harsh condition was determined as shown in Fig. 5 . It is obviously noted that that during the 30 h test, no obvious deactivation of the catalyst at 430−470 °C with HCl/O2 of 2–4 is observed. Comparatively, the stable run could not be achieved under the same condition over CeO2 cubes, CeO2 octahedrons, and CexZr1-xO2 catalysts, because of the forming of CeCl3n H2O, as reported in literature [8,11]. It is also revealed that the higher the reaction temperature is, the higher the X HCl can be obtained, consistent with the previous results under the mild reaction conditions. When the reaction temperature reaches 490 °C, the activity decreases in the first several hours, and then goes to stable, which may be ascribed to the sintering of the catalyst due to the high reaction temperature and the exothermal nature of the reaction. Because the calcination temperature of the catalyst during the preparation process is 550 °C, the second sintering occurs on the catalyst when the reaction temperature is close to this value, leading to the decrease of the activity in the initial reaction stage. After the sintering process is completed, the HCl conversion keeps stable. The lower the reaction temperature is, the less significant is the sintering of catalyst, which can be identified by the following XRD results. The surface structure of three samples, including the fresh CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst and those used at 430 °C and 450 °C and HCl/O2 = 4 for 30 h, were characterized by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 6 , the fresh catalyst exhibits a wide peak at around 645 cm–1, which is related to defect-induced mode of CeO2, suggesting the high dispersion of CeO2 on the surface. After reaction at 430 °C and 450 °C, the peak at 645 cm–1 becomes obviously weakened, and a new peak at 455 cm−1 appears which is attributed to the F2g vibration mode of cubic fluorite-type CeO2 [24]. This suggests the growth of the surface CeO2 to higher crystallinity during reaction. According to the literature [25], the peak position for the F2g mode was the function of inverse CeO2 crystal size, and the measured peak position shifted to lower energies with decreasing CeO2 crystal size. According to the models [26,27], the CeO2 crystal size of the used catalyst at 430 ℃ and 450 ℃ for 30 h are evaluated to be roughly 5.81 nm and 8.69 nm, respectively. In addition, the BET specific surface area of these three samples was characterized by N2 adsorption instrument. The result shows that after the continuous 30 h run at 430 °C and 450 °C, the BET specific surface area of the catalyst decreases from 159 m2/g to 107 m2/g and 91 m2/g, respectively, suggesting the occurrence of slight sintering during reaction. Furthermore, XRD characterization was carried out to detect all the used catalysts, and the results were shown in Fig. 7 . The different degrees of sintering of the catalyst at varied reaction temperatures can be observed according to the peak sharpness at 28.5°of the (111) plane of CeO2, which is the reason for the stability results in Fig. 5. Among all the used catalysts, the obvious bulk chlorination is only observed for the catalyst used under the reaction temperature of 430 °C and HCl/O2 = 4, and the characteristic peak of MnCl22 H2O appears (Fig. 7d). In contrast, for all other catalysts, the XRD patterns keep almost the same as that of the fresh catalyst. Even under the harshest condition with HCl/O2 of 4, the increase of reaction temperature to 450 °C can efficiently avoid the bulk chlorination. Compared with the traditional CeO2 based catalyst reported in literatures [1,7,8,11], the best anti-chlorination catalyst CeO2@ZrO2 could keep stable under the condition with HCl/O2 of 3. Therefore, CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 is proved to be an efficient anti-chlorination catalyst so far, and utilizing the reaction temperature above 450 °C is an simple and efficient way to keep the stability. 4 Conclusions The effect of high temperature on the activity and stability of CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst was investigated. First of all, the STY increased sharply from 3.0 to 9.5 gCl2 gcat −1 h−1 at X HCl of 65 % when the reaction temperature was increased from 430 °C to 490 °C. Secondly, CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst could keep stable for at least 30 h at 450−490 °C even with HCl/O2 of 4. The pulse intake experiments of HCl and O2 showed that increasing the reaction temperature could reduce the coverage of Cl* on the catalyst surface and hence maintain the adsorption balance of Cl* and O*. Finally, the bulk chlorination of catalyst could be inhibited even with HCl/O2 of 4, so long as the reaction temperature was higher than 450 °C. coredata.dc:description: The effect of high reaction temperature on the activity and stability of CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst was investigated. The space time yield (STY) of Cl2 was significantly increased from 3.0 to 9.5 gCl2 gcat −1 h−1 at the same X HCl of 65 % by increasing reaction temperature from 430 to 490 °C and the catalyst could keep stable for at least 30 h under the harsh condition with HCl/O2 of 4. The pulse intake experiments results of HCl and O2 showed that increasing the reaction temperature from 430 °C to 490 °C was conducive to keep the adsorption balance of Cl* and O* on the catalyst surface, which was the key reason for the increase of STY and stability. The XRD characterization results verified the crystalline stability of CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 catalyst at 450 °C with HCl/O2 of 4. In this paper, CeO2(12)-MnO x (13)/Al2O3 was proved to be a high active and excellent anti-chlorination catalyst at high reaction temperature, which supplied a novel alternative for the industrial application.
coredata.dc:title: Improved Cl2 yield and stability of CeO2-MnOx/Al2O3 catalyst for HCl oxidation to Cl2 at higher reaction temperature
